page.text: 548 Bennington St. Apt. #3
East Boston MA, 02128
City of Cambridge Afterschool Program: Cambridge, MA
Responsible for running the 2
nd
th
grade afterschool program at the Morse Elementary School and
working in the classroom everyday with students and staff.
Worked with a population of students and families that represent a wide variety of countries and
rage of socioeconomic statuses. Familiar with many different families’ cultures and how those
shape their parenting styles.
Developed classroom curricula including planning lessons for ongoing project based learning and
field trips for school vacation weeks.
Provided academic support for students, conducting classroom observations, and meetings with
learning specialists to develop homework plans for IEP students. Served as a liaison between
school -day teachers and parents.
Worked with children who have special needs and or behavioral issues; worked with inclusion
specialists to design individualized behavior plans and provide support for students.
Ensured that the program site met Early Education and Care (EEC) requirements for licensing
inspections.
Supervised staff, conducted staff and supervision meetings. Ensured the staff worked to meet the
department’s guidelines for quality programming, participation in department required Quality
Rating Improvement System (QRIS).
Participated in ongoing professional development.
Center for Youth - Hands on Hartford: Hartford, CT August 2007-March 2008
Taught children from Hartford’s poorest neighborhoods, in both Spanish and English, in the 2
nd
grade afterschool class at the Betances Elementary school. Core responsibilities included
preparing lesson plans that met Board of Education guidelines.
Worked with team members to provide special events at the center and culturally relative fieldtrips.
Worked as a team with other staff members and certified specialists for training on childhood
behavioral problems, learning differences and cultural differences.
Assisted children with homework.
Arts Education International: Boulder, CO March 2006- July 2010
Non-Profit Organization geared towards bringing the arts and education to orphanages in other
countries through workshops with local and U.S. artists. Sites currently include Ghana, Sierra
Leone, and Trinidad and Tobago.
Served as a liaison between U.S and local artists and educators for program sites in Trinidad and
Tobago.
Founder, Artistic Expressions : Hartford, CT September 2004- May 2007

i.b: Charter Oak Cultural Center, Hartford, CT

page.text: Created and implemented a new after-school art program for elementary and middle school age
children. Recruited students from the Betances Elementary School and Hartford’s Center for
Youth.
Taught (or supervised) all class sessions.
Researched and wrote numerous grants to secure funding for Artistic Expressions.
Managed program budget including purchase of art supplies and classroom materials.
Established an affiliation with Trinity College’s Urban Engagement Curriculum, allowing students to
receive academic credit for internships undertaken with Artistic Expressions.
Trinity Urban Leadership Program (TULP): Hartford, CT Summer 2006
Researched the 920 Broad Park Detention Center and the operation of the juvenile justice system
and the treatment of status offenders. Research included internal and external sources.
Researched information about current and past Connecticut legislation working in conjunction with
the Youth Rights Media Group from New Haven Connecticut, Mi Casa, DCF, Trinity Center for
Designed and filmed a documentary project about the detention centers.
Broad Park Development: Hartford, CT
Organized quality- of- life meetings between city residents and community organizations.
Conducted door- to- door surveys with Broad Park residents about community concerns.
Project involved extensive Spanish-English translation (both written and verbal).
Distributed information for community conversations in various tenant housing locations.

text.b: Community Learning Initiative Focus Group: Hartford, CT

page.text: Worked with students active in Community service and urban initiatives from Trinity College as well as professors
in brainstorming ideas for classes focused on urban engagement, community learning, internship projects and
working to get more students involved in the greater Hartford area. Spoke annually as a panelist for Trinity’s
Urban Engagement Conference.
Tutorial College: Hartford, CT
Elected member of the Tutorial Honor Council. Responsibilities include Resident Assistant duties
such as conducting Health and Safety Inspections and scheduled fire drills. Advised disciplinary
action for Tutorial residents with school violations in conjunction with the Trinity College Office of
Residential Life (ORL).

text.b: Semester Abroad in Trinidad and Tobago

page.text: Studied Sociology for degree credit at the University of West Indies, specifically doing ethnographic
research around steel panyards.
Internship with the professional dance company Malick Folk Performers, did live performances at Carnival,
Dimanche Gras, and other shows.
BA in Sociology, Trinity College, Hartford, CT
Samuel S. Fishzohn Award for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, given in recognition of a student chosen who
has exhibited initiative and creativity in community service related to important social issues, and dedication in
civil rights, civil liberties or race relations. Trinity College Honor’s Day Academic Award, May 2007.
Higher Education Community Service Award, a statewide award from the Connecticut Commission on
Community Service and the Office of Higher Education and the Deputy Commissioner of Higher Education for the
development of Artistic Expressions at the Charter Oak Cultural Center. April 2007.
Early Childhood Education: Familiar with MCAS Testing Preparation and Certified in TERC Method, and
Cambridge Public Learning strands and Core Knowledge.
Language: Proficient in reading, speaking, and writing Spanish.
Computers: Proficient with Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Wiki Works.
Excellent interpersonal communication skills.
